[Christmas](/wiki/Christmas) - Food portal - v - t - e **Murtabak**, or **mutabbaq** ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language): مُطَبَّق, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic): *muṭabbaq*, [lit.](/wiki/Literal_translation) 'folded', [standard](/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic) pronunciation: [mu.tˤab.baq]), is a Yemeni stuffed [pancake](/wiki/Pancake) or pan-fried bread commonly found in the [Arabian Peninsula](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula), the [Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent), and [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia), notably in [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia), [Yemen](/wiki/Yemen), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), [Brunei](/wiki/Brunei), and [Southern Thailand](/wiki/Southern_Thailand). Depending on the location, the name and ingredients can vary significantly. The name *mutabbaq* means "folded" in Arabic. Murtabak is often described as a spicy folded [omelette](/wiki/Omelette) or pancake with bits of vegetables. Its most common form is made from pan-fried [crepes](/wiki/Crepe), usually stuffed with beaten eggs, chopped [leeks](/wiki/Leek), [chives](/wiki/Chives), or [green onion](/wiki/Green_onion), and [minced meat](/wiki/Ground_meat), which is then folded and cut into squares. In Malaysia, murtabak was originally sold in [mamak stalls](/wiki/Mamak_stall), and usually includes minced meat (beef or chicken, sometimes [goat meat](/wiki/Goat_meat) or mutton) along with garlic, egg, and onion, and is eaten with curry, sliced cucumber, syrup-pickled onions, or tomato sauce. In Indonesia, the term *martabak* refers to two dishes: *[martabak manis](/wiki/Martabak_manis)*, based on *apam balik*, and *martabak telur*, which resembles murtabak the closest and includes egg, meat, and [scallions](/wiki/Scallion). A thinner variant of *martabak manis* is *martabak tipis kering*. ## History 13th-Century [Abbasid](/wiki/Abbasid) author [Muhammad bin Hasan al-Baghdadi](/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Hasan_al-Baghdadi) wrote two recipes for *muṭbaq* مطبق in his book titled *Kitab al-Tabikh*, they described a dish made with 2 layers of bread and enveloping a sweet filling. The word *mutabbaq* in [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic) means "folded". This suggests that murtabak might originate from [Yemen](/wiki/Yemen), which had a sizeable Indian population; through Indian traders it spread back to their home countries. Murtabak was then brought to Southeast Asia by Tamil Muslim traders. Another version of muttabaq was created by a former [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire) soldier named Mohammed Zalatimo in the [Old City of Jerusalem](/wiki/Old_City_of_Jerusalem) in 1860. His version was paper-thin folded filo dough filled with local white cheese; its name was derived from the act of layering [yufka sheets](/wiki/Filo). The exact origin of the craft of creating multilayer-dough sweets is debated, with some tracing it to [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia). In countries where martabak is widely available, it is so common it has become an everyday dish. This dish is made not only at home, but often found in inexpensive food service menus specialising in traditional cuisine, which is why it has the reputation of street food.[*citation needed*] Sometimes martabak – especially sweet – go on sale in stores already in finished form. ## Variants ### Savoury #### South East Asia There are many varieties of martabak. For example, in Brunei, most martabaks are usually not stuffed, but only made of dough (called *martabak kosong*) similar to the Indian [paratha](/wiki/Paratha). *Martabak kosong* consists of a bread-like dough that is kneaded and prepared similarly to a pancake or other martabak by tossing it into the air, and served piping hot with a sweet curry sauce. In Singapore and Malaysia (where it is called murtabak), the murtabaks are usually filled with spiced beef, chicken or mutton and served with a curry sauce, sweet pickled onions or cucumber in ketchup. Another variant in Malaysia and Singapore is murtabak cheese which uses mozzarella cheese as additional filling. Johorean (Malaysia) and Singaporean murtabak uses more minced meat than most Malaysian murtabak.[*citation needed*] The common ingredients of Indonesian egg martabak, besides the dough, is seasoned ground meat (beef, chicken or mutton), sliced green onions, some herbs (optional), beaten duck eggs, salt, and potatoes. Some street vendors mix the ground beef with curry seasoning. In Indonesia, the common spices to make the seasoned ground meat are [shallots](/wiki/Shallots), garlic, [ginger](/wiki/Ginger), [cumin](/wiki/Cumin), [coriander](/wiki/Coriander), [turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric), some salt, and sometimes a little bit of [monosodium glutamate](/wiki/Monosodium_glutamate). All the spices are ground or minced and stir-fried altogether. Some martabak makers add extra ingredients and other varieties to make their martabak unique, but they all share the same main dough. To [fry](/wiki/Frying) martabak, the chef uses a very large flat frying pan or iron [griddle](/wiki/Griddle). Usually they use vegetable oil to fry, but it is not uncommon to use [ghee](/wiki/Ghee) or butter too. Before serving, martabak usually is cut into portions. Sometimes it is eaten with sweet and salty soy sauce and pepper. Savoury versions of martabak in Indonesia and Malaysia usually are served with [acar](/wiki/Acar) or [pickled](/wiki/Pickling) condiment consisting of diced cucumber, sliced carrot, shallots, and sliced [chillies](/wiki/Chili_pepper) in sweetened vinegar whereas in Singapore, the condiment consists of sliced cucumbers in tomato ketchup. In Malaysia, Singapore and some areas in [Sumatra](/wiki/Sumatra), martabak is served with *kari* ([curry](/wiki/Curry)) gravy. In Palembang, another variety of martabak is egg-martabak (eggs dropped into the flatten dough before folded while frying) served in curry (usually diced potatoes in beef curry) and topped with chillies in sweet-sour soy sauce called *Martabak Haji Abdul Rozak*, or more commonly known as *Martabak HAR*, made popular by an [Indian Indonesian](/wiki/Indian_Indonesians) named Haji Abdul Rozak. There is also a popular martabak variant from [Padang](/wiki/Padang), [West Sumatra](/wiki/West_Sumatra) called *Martabak Kubang*, which is served with light curry as dipping sauce. Another variety of martabak, especially in Malaysia and Sumatra (such as in [Jambi](/wiki/Jambi_City), [Palembang](/wiki/Palembang), and [Lampung](/wiki/Lampung)), is one called *martabak kentang* (potato-stuffed martabak). It usually uses the similar dough as other martabak, but it is stuffed with a mix of diced potatoes, beaten eggs, chopped green onions, and spices instead of beaten egg and ground beef. It is eaten by dipping it into hot sweet-sour soy sauce or curry sauce. There are many varieties of martabak, specifically in Indonesia, where various types of emerging toppings are being added to innovate the dish. Toppings that are used to substitute the meat are black-pepper-sauced minced meat, spicy tuna, shredded [beef rendang](/wiki/Rendang), grilled salmon and [instant noodles](/wiki/Instant_noodles). The popular common instant noodle toppings being used are [Indomie](/wiki/Indomie) and [Samyang spicy noodles](/wiki/Hot_Chicken_Flavor_Ramen). [Mozzarella cheese](/wiki/Mozzarella) is sprinkled outside the fried martabak and then torched to get a melty consistency.[*citation needed*] #### South Africa The *muttabah* of [Cape Malays](/wiki/Cape_Malays) in South Africa is mainly filled with minced meat and spinach with a cheese topping. #### Levant *Muttabaq zaatar* ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language): مطبق زعتر) is a traditional [Palestinian](/wiki/Palestine_(Region)) muttabaq made by folding dough over fresh za'atar ([Origanum syriacum](/wiki/Origanum_syriacum)) leaves, onions and [sumac](/wiki/Sumac), which is then baked and topped with olive oil. ### Sweet Another variety of martabak is called *martabak manis* (sweet martabak), also known by the name *[Terang Bulan](/wiki/Apam_balik)* or *Martabak [Bangka](/wiki/Bangka-Belitung_Islands)*. This naming however, is only valid in Indonesia, since the identical folded thick pancake is called *[apam balik](/wiki/Apam_balik)* instead in Malaysia.[*citation needed*] Despite sharing the same name (because they are both folded), the cooking method, dough (which uses [yeast](/wiki/Yeast) and [baking soda](/wiki/Baking_soda)), and the ingredients (usually vanilla extract is added as essence) are different from egg martabak, giving it a consistency more like a [crumpet](/wiki/Crumpet). While it is baked on a pan, the sweet martabak is spread with butter or margarine, sugar, crushed peanuts, chocolate sprinkles, cheese or other toppings. Before serving, the martabak is folded in half, so the toppings get in the middle of martabak. In parts of Indonesia, egg martabak may also be called *Martabak [Malabar](/wiki/Malabar_region)* to distinguish it from sweet martabak.[*citation needed*] There are many new varieties of *martabak manis*, including the addition of green tea powder ([matcha](/wiki/Matcha)), cream cheese, [Oreo](/wiki/Oreo), and chocolate candies such as [Hagelslag](/wiki/Hagelslag), [Kit Kat](/wiki/Kit_Kat), [Ovomaltine](/wiki/Ovomaltine), [Toblerone](/wiki/Toblerone) and [Nutella](/wiki/Nutella). Aside from that, durian fruits are often used as a topping. [*citation needed*] When ordering Martabak Manis, some stall offer two choice of [margarine](/wiki/Margarine): [Blue Band](/wiki/Blue_Band_(brand)) margarine or Wijsman butter. The Wijsman butter is more costly compared to Blueband margarine as the Wijsman is made by 100% cow [milk fat](/wiki/Milk_fat). In some areas in the [Levant](/wiki/Levant), a sweet version is made using nuts or unsalted cheese as filling, and topped with a [sugar syrup](/wiki/Qatir_(syrup)). Traditionally, sweetened *[jibneh baladi](/wiki/Baladi_cheese)* is used. - Food portal - India portal - Indonesia portal - Malaysia portal - Singapore portal - Yemen portal - [Saudi Arabian cuisine](/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_cuisine) - [Yemeni cuisine](/wiki/Yemeni_cuisine) - [Malaysian cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) - [Singaporean cuisine](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) - [Indonesian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine) - [Indian cuisine](/wiki/Indian_cuisine) - [List of egg dishes](/wiki/List_of_egg_dishes) - [List of pancakes](/wiki/List_of_pancakes) - [List of stuffed dishes](/wiki/List_of_stuffed_dishes) - [Okonomiyaki](/wiki/Okonomiyaki) - [Roti canai](/wiki/Roti_canai) ## Notes - Retno Savitri. *Masakan & Jalanan Favorit: Kumpulan Resep.* — Jakarta: Better Book Niaga Swadaya Group, 2008. — 305 p. — [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 978-602-8060-07-3 - Husni Rasyad, Retnowati, Eddy SL. title: Murtabak
